Mr. Fisher informed Mr. Dugas that the government proposed to establish several illustration stations in regard to the ſeeding of poultry, the culture of various sorts of roots, and grain, though not fruit trees. Most of these will be operated during the year 1900. One station would be for growing and curing tobacco in Montcalm.

ONLY TO THE LIVING.

Mr. Hughes was informed that the imperial dispatch granting medals for the Fenian raid and the Red River rebellion, directed that such medals were to be issued only to living parti­cipants and not to the families of the participants, who have died since.

Mr. Ciarke was informed by Mr. Sir. ton that last year Callada paid to British steamship men seven shillings per head for Jimmigrants twelve years old or over, brought ſrom Britain to Canada, and half that amount for children. PRINTING WOTERS’ LISTS. Ottawa, April 28,-In the house to­day, in committee in supply, a vote on “contingent expenses in collnection , with the voters list,” caused consid: erable discussion. Several members of the opposition held that the franchise act required that lists should be print­ed within a limited period after their receipt from the municipal custodians and held that $2,500 would not be a sufficient amount for the expenses. Sir Louis Davies said the vote was not for the printing of all the lists, but to meet special cases, such as the Brockville and Winnipeg bye-elections. The franchise act was read by Mr. Casgrain, to show that the intention was that the lists should be printed within a limited time aſter their re­ceipt by the clerk of the crown in chancery. Every member of parlia­ment, it was provided, should be furnished with a certain number of copies of the lists. Now, this was not done last year, and there was no vote to do it this year: Sir louis Davies replied, and said that it would cost over $60,000, and if the house decided to do this it would be done, but he did not think it was necessary. Mr. Lariviere, Provencher, claimed this was an injustice in Manitoba,

where there were no lists. In connection with the discussion Mr. N. Clarke Wallace charged that Con­servatives had not been able to get any iists for Brockville until after no; mination day, while the Liberals had them before it. Mr. Blair said he had the authority of the secretary of state that an equal number of Brockville lists had been sent to both candidates by the same mail on the same day. He said he was sure no party would treat opponents so unfairly as alleged. The item stood.

MINISTER OF MILITIA.

The minister of militia made a num­ber of interesting reſiections about Mr. Hughes and his scheme and even criti­cized Mr. Sproule for his strictness concerning it, especially with regard to the disparaging remarks concerning discharged soldiers. Dr. Borden said that though he was minister of militia he did not desire to give undue promi­mence to the building up of a spirit of miltarism in this country but the proper idea was to be able to defend ourseſves and aid the civil authority in case of necessity. He held that we had quite enough to do ſor some years to come to perſect our own militia aud that it would be time enough then to take up the question involved in Mr Hughes' resolution. He thought that at that time the desired end would come about naturally. He conciuded by saying that the premier had taken the mºst important step yet with regard to the unification of the empire by his preferentiaſ tariſſ and he asked Mr. Hughes to withdraw his resolution as his purpose had been served by bring­ing it to the attention of the house and of the public. Mr. Hughes agreed to this. - - | |

Ottawa, May 2–The position of Canada, the financial operations of the past year, and the prospects finan. cial and cominercial were described by the minister of finance this aſternoon in the annual Budget. It was Mr. Fielding's most brilliant speech, and aroused the greatest enthusiasm, on the ministerial benches. The public galleries were crowded, and the sen­ators gallery Well filled. No tariff changes were announced. All coai oil inspection ſees and all reg­ulations, except those for safety, are abolished. Oil which is ſound not lip to required standard will be conſis­cated. The members advocating the oil interests are not well pleased ºt this announcement. The changes will reduce the price of coal oil consider: ably by inviting the independent oil men in the U. S. to enter the Cana­dian Iriarket more freely than at present. The reduced taxes last year Were estimated to amount to $3,000,000. The surplus last year was stated to be $1,722,000. The surplus for this year will be $4,600,000. + w The net increase to the debt last year was $2,417,000; this year, it will only be $1,700,000, with large public improvements and railway sub­sidies all met. - The financial statement gave great satisfaction to the Liberal members and other friends of government. REYENUE AND EXPENDITURE. In opening, Mr. Fielding said he had the pſeasure of dealing with the most prosperous period of Canada's history. P. O. SEHOWING.

Thanks to the business-like manage­ment of the postmaster-generai, the revenue of the postoffice department increased $324,871, and the expendi­ture decreased $214,066, a betterment in that department of $538,937. This improvement led to the reduction of thé domestic postage rate and the in­troduction of imperial penny postage. (Cheers).

A BIG SURPLUS.

Taking up the consolidated ſund ſig­ures the minister of finance said there was a surplus ſor the year ending June 30 last, of $1,722,712, made up as follows: Revenue $40, ,238; expen­ditures $38,832 , surplus $1,722,­712. Thus expectation that the $519,000 deficit of the previous year would be made up by a surplus in 1897-8, was more than made good. (Cheers).

CAPITAL ExPENDITURE.

The actual capital expenditure of 1837-S was $4,156,696. To this $1,­414,924 of railway subsidies should be added, making a total capital expen­diture of $5,571,631. . After paying for this outlay and making a provision for $930,482, representing the dis­count, and the expense of the loan of

1897, the net debt increase was $2,­4.17,802. - The following statement was sub­

mitted to show how the increase in the debt is accounted ſor: Capital ex­penditure and railway subsidies, $5,­571,631; discount on the expenses of the loan of 1897, $930,482; total $6,­502,113, less the amount of receipts over expenditure on account of con­solidated ſund, $1,722, 712; sinking fund, $2,359,968; reſunds on account of public works, capital and Northwest rebellion, $100,030, total $4,084,311, leaving a net increase of $2,417,802.

ANOTHER SURPLUS, The finance minister next dealt with the figures of the present financial year ending June 30th, 1899. Up to April 30th, the receipts were $37,237,­7ū() which is $5,077,160 more than for the same period last year. Mr. Fielding estimated receipts for the year at $46,632,398 and expenditure $42,076,078, which will leave in round numbers a surplus of $4,600,­()00. (Cheers.) In consequence of the buoyancy of trade and the uncer­tainty of the Yukon gold royalty the surplus may be larger even than this. The minister next dealt with the capi­tal expenditure ſor this year and its effect on the net debt. The capital expenſliture and subsidies to April 1st was $7,162,795. Estimates to coin­plete the year, $1,500,000. Total $8,­662,795. Deducting from this the es­timated surplus and sinking ſund the net addition to the national debt this year will be $1,700,000. - “I see the honorable gentlemen smile,” said Mr. Fielding to some of the members of the opposition, “at the modesty of the addition. With this small addition we have carried on great public works and we place it against your average of six miliions per year increase.” (Liberal cheers.) Coming down to the coming fiscal year, 1899-1900, Mr. Fielding said that he could not make an estimate with any degree of certainty.
